title: CITY GOVERNMENT OF ADDIS ABABA EDUCATION BUREAU ARADA SUB-CITY EDUCATION OFFICE 2017 E.C 1ST SEMISTER ECONOMICS GRADE 12TH MODEL EXAMINATIONS TIME ALLOWED 2:30

questions.text: Which of the following defines marginal utility?
options: The change in total utility divided by the price of a product.
The maximum amount of satisfaction from consuming a product.
The total satisfaction received from consuming as much of the product that is available for consumption.
The additional satisfaction received from consuming one more unit of a product.
questions.explanation: Marginal utility is the additional satisfaction received from consuming one more unit of a product.

questions.text: Which one of the following is best expresses the law of diminishing marginal utility?
options: The more consumption of a product, the smaller is the total and marginal utility from the consumption.
The less consumption of a product, the greater is the total and marginal utility of the consumption.
The more consumption of a product, the smaller is the marginal utility from consuming an additional unit.
The more consumption of a product, the smaller is the total and marginal utility from the consumption.
questions.explanation: The law of diminishing marginal utility states that the more consumption of a product, the smaller is the marginal utility from consuming an additional unit.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect statement about characteristics of indifference curve?
options: Indifference curves are convex to the origin.
Indifference curves can cross each other.
The further indifference curve away from the origin gives high level of satisfaction.
questions.explanation: Indifference curves cannot cross each other.

questions.text: All are assumptions of ordinal utility theory except one.
questions.explanation: Utility is cardinal is not an assumption of ordinal utility theory.

questions.text: Consider two goods, X and Y. If the consumer is indifferent between consuming bundles of (10X, 5Y) and (5X, 10Y) then, what kind of relationship exists between the goods?
options: Cannot be determined from this information
questions.explanation: If the consumer is indifferent between the bundles, the goods are perfect substitutes.

questions.text: The locus of combinations or bundle of goods that can be purchased if all the income spent is -
questions.explanation: The budget line represents the combinations of goods that can be purchased if all the income is spent.

questions.text: When a consumer is below his budget line rather than on it, this implies that the consumer
options: Has spent all of his income.
Did not spend all of his/her personal.
questions.explanation: Being below the budget line implies that the consumer did not spend all of his/her income.

questions.text: If the consumer’s income is Birr 900 and the price of X is Birr 8 per unit and the price of Y is Birr 16 per unit then, calculate the slope of budget line.
questions.explanation: The slope of the budget line is -(Px/Py) = -(8/16) = -0.5.

questions.text: Given two commodities X and Y and level of income M, if price of good X decreases (money income and price of Y remaining the same), which of the following is true?
options: The budget line rotates to the left.
The budget line rotates inward for the X commodity.
The slope of the budget line remains the same.
The budget line rotates outward for the X commodity.
questions.explanation: If the price of X decreases, the budget line rotates outward for the X commodity.

questions.text: At equilibrium, the slope of highest attainable indifference curve is:
options: Greater than the slope of the budget line
Less than the slope of the budget line
Equal to the slope of the budget line
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, the slope of the highest attainable indifference curve is equal to the slope of the budget line.

questions.text: The main criteria to classify or distinguish markets are
questions.explanation: Markets are classified based on the nature of the product.

questions.text: Based on the numbers of firm in the market which one indicates correctly chronological order from largest to smallest.
options: Monopoly - Oligopoly - Monopolistic Competition - Perfect Competition
Oligopoly - Monopolistic Competition - Monopoly - Perfect Competition
Monopolistic Competition - Perfect Competition - Oligopoly - Monopoly
Perfect Competition - Monopolistic Competition - Oligopoly - Monopoly
questions.explanation: The correct order from largest to smallest number of firms is Perfect Competition - Monopolistic Competition - Oligopoly - Monopoly.

questions.text: Perfect competition is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT
options: Well-informed buyers and sellers with respect to prices.
A large number of buyers and sellers.
No restrictions on entry into or exit from the industry.
questions.explanation: Perfect competition does not involve considerable advertising by individual firms.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the long-run equilibrium of perfectly competitive firms EXCEPT
options: The downward portion of long-run average cost curve is tangent to the demand curve, then long run equilibrium is achieved.
The minimum long-run average cost curve is tangent to the demand curve then, long run equilibrium is achieved.
Firms in perfectly competitive market earn a normal profit.
Price and average cost of the firm are equal due to free entry
questions.explanation: The downward portion of the long-run average cost curve being tangent to the demand curve does not achieve long-run equilibrium.

questions.text: Perfectly competitive firm has a marginal cost function of MC = 2Q + 20 and the equilibrium price is Birr 100. Find the profit maximizing level of output.
questions.explanation: To find the profit-maximizing level of output, set MC = P. 2Q + 20 = 100 => 2Q = 80 => Q = 40.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT true about reasons for the existence of monopolies?
options: Ownership of strategic or key input
questions.explanation: Diseconomies of scale in production is not a reason for the existence of monopolies.

questions.text: What is the difference between first degree and second degree price discrimination in monopoly market?
options: The first charges different price based on amount but the second charges different price based on consumer’s ability.
The first charges different price based on consumer’s ability but the second charges different price based on amount.
The first charges different price based on divided the market into sub market but the second charges different price based on amount.
The first charges different price based on amount but the second charges different price based on divided the market into sub market.
questions.explanation: First-degree price discrimination charges different prices based on the amount, while second-degree price discrimination charges different prices based on the consumer's ability.

questions.text: Which market structure differentiates product?
questions.explanation: Monopolistic competition differentiates products.

questions.text: What is the difference between perfect competition and monopolistic competition?
options: Perfect competition has a large number of small firms while monopolistic competition does not.
In perfect competition, firms produce identical goods, while in monopolistic competition, firms produce slightly different goods.
Perfect competition has no barriers to entry, while monopolistic competition does.
Perfect competition has barriers to entry while monopolistic competition does not.
questions.explanation: Perfect competition has no barriers to entry, while monopolistic competition does.

questions.text: Which one of the following are not the features of oligopoly firm?
options: Few dominant firms in the market
questions.explanation: Oligopoly firms have few dominant firms in the market, not many sellers and buyers.

questions.text: If a firm sells its output on a market that is characterized by few sellers and many buyers and limited long-run resource mobility, then the firm is
questions.explanation: The firm is an oligopolistic firm.

questions.text: Which one are not the reasons of National income accounting practice is good for an economy?
options: It enables us to know the level of output of an economy.
To observe the short-run trend of the economy.
It helps in policy formulation since it can be used as evidence in policy making.
questions.explanation: National income accounting practice helps in observing the long-run trend of the economy, not the short-run trend.

questions.text: Which one of the following is best describe national income accounting?
options: It is regional measurements of economy of the world.
It is official measurement of flow of income and product.
It is the official measure of income only in the economy.
It measures net transfers and aids only.
questions.explanation: National income accounting is the official measurement of the flow of income and product.

questions.text: Which one of the following statement is false EXCEPT.
options: National income accounting is represented by GDP.
GDP is wider concept than GNP
GDP measures both territorial products and factor income.
GDP is not official measure of flow of income and products.
questions.explanation: GDP is the official measure of the flow of income and products.

questions.text: Which one of the following statement correctly represent GNP?
options: It is the difference between GDP and factor income.
It is a flow concept but not stock measure.
It measures the only factors of production produced in a country.
It measures the market value of human labour in the economy
questions.explanation: GNP is the difference between GDP and factor income.

questions.text: Which one of the following statement is false about product approach of measuring GDP except.
options: It is the market value of all final goods and services.
It is the market values of all intermediate goods.
It is the market value of only necessity goods.
It is the amount of money collected by sellers on final goods and services.
questions.explanation: The product approach of measuring GDP includes the market value of all final goods and services, not intermediate goods.

questions.text: Which statement is correct about trade balance?
options: It is the difference between buying to foreigner and sell to foreigners
It may be deficit when export greater than import.
It may be surplus when export less than import.
It may be balance when import less than export.
questions.explanation: Trade balance is the difference between exports and imports.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT common problem of measuring GDP?
options: The existence of large informal sector.
questions.explanation: Transfer payments and aids are not a common problem of measuring GDP.

questions.text: Which statement is false about nominal and real GDP?
options: Nominal GDP is measured by constant price but real GDP is measured by current price.
Nominal GDP is valued by current price but real GDP is measured by constant price.
Nominal GDP increases when the amount of goods and services increases.
Real GDP increases when either output or price increases.
questions.explanation: Nominal GDP is valued by current prices, while real GDP is measured by constant prices.

questions.text: The measure of price typical basket of goods bought by firm.
questions.explanation: The GDP deflator measures the price of a typical basket of goods bought by firms.

questions.text: Which one of the following statement is true about price index?
options: GDP deflator measures the price of producer goods but CPI measures only consumer goods
GDP deflator measures the price of both producer and consumer goods but CPI measures goods bought by consumers.
Both GDP deflator and CPI measure the same thing.
Increase in imported goods affects GDP deflator.
questions.explanation: GDP deflator measures the price of both producer and consumer goods, while CPI measures the price of goods bought by consumers.

questions.text: If consumer has 3000ETB and makes consumption expenditure of 2000ETB, the APC of a household is:
questions.explanation: APC (Average Propensity to Consume) = Consumption Expenditure / Income = 2000ETB / 3000ETB = 0.66.

questions.text: Which one of the following statement is true?
options: APC is greater than 1 when income is very high.
APC is less than 1 when income is very low
APC is greater than 1 when income is very low.
APC is equal to 1 when income is very low
questions.explanation: APC is greater than 1 when income is very low.

questions.text: An increase in consumer confidence is MOST likely to lead to:
options: A decrease in the marginal propensity to consume
questions.explanation: An increase in consumer confidence is most likely to lead to an increase in overall consumption.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of marginal propensity to consume (MPC)?
options: The total amount of income spent on consumption.
The proportion of total income that is saved.
The change in consumption resulting from a change in income.
The average level of consumption over time
questions.explanation: MPC is the change in consumption resulting from a change in income.

questions.text: If the marginal propensity to save (MPS) is 0.2, what is the marginal propensity to consume (MPC)?
What is the primary purpose of investment in economics?
options: To increase future production and income.
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of investment in economics is to increase future production and income.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a component of business investment?
questions.explanation: Government bonds are not typically considered a component of business investment.

questions.text: What does the term 'present value' refer to in the context of investment?
options: The original cost of an asset
The current value of a future sum of money.
The expected profit from an investment.
The total costs associated with an investment.
questions.explanation: Present value refers to the current value of a future sum of money.

questions.text: Suppose BEKELE has a monthly income of $3,000 and he wants to save 15% of it. What is the amount he allocates to save in each month?
What would be the consequence of a country consistently having a trade deficit?
options: A consistent increase in the country's GDP
A constant increase in the country's standard of living
A decrease in the country's net exports which negatively affects the GDP
A significant increase in local production
questions.explanation: A consistent trade deficit leads to a decrease in the country's net exports, which negatively affects the GDP.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key measure of national income?
questions.explanation: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is a key measure of national income.

questions.text: The expenditure approach to calculating GDP includes which of the following components?
options: Consumption, investment, government spending, and net exports.
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach to calculating GDP includes consumption, investment, government spending, and net exports.

questions.text: Which approach to measuring GDP is most likely to be affected by changes in inventory levels?
options: The production and income approaches are equally affected by inventory.
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach to measuring GDP is most likely to be affected by changes in inventory levels.

questions.text: An economy experiences a decline in business investment and an increase in consumer spending. What would likely be the impact on the different approaches to calculating GDP?
options: Both approaches will measure the same decline in GDP.
Both approaches will measure the same increase in GDP.
The expenditure approach will show a smaller increase than the income approach.
The expenditure approach may show a smaller impact than the income approach, due to less production, but the results will be the same.
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach may show a smaller impact than the income approach due to less production, but the results will be the same.

questions.text: What is a potential limitation of using the income approach to measure GDP?
options: It can be difficult to accurately measure all types of income.
It fails to account for government
questions.explanation: It can be difficult to accurately measure all types of income using the income approach.

questions.text: Which of the following is a potential weakness of the expenditure approach to measuring GDP?
options: It does not capture all economic activities within a given economy.
It includes double counting of the value of goods and services.
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach does not capture all economic activities within a given economy.

questions.text: Why are firms in an oligopoly considered 'mutually interdependent'?
options: Because they operate completely independently of each other.
Because their actions directly impact each other's profits.
Because they all share the same production methods.
questions.explanation: Firms in an oligopoly are considered mutually interdependent because their actions directly impact each other's profits.

questions.text: How does product differentiation affect firms in an oligopoly?
options: Reduces the power of each individual firm.
Increases the power of each individual firm.
Has no impact on the firms' power.
Encourages perfect competition in the market.
questions.explanation: Product differentiation increases the power of each individual firm in an oligopoly.

questions.text: Which one of the following is false in perfectly competitive market?
questions.explanation: In a perfectly competitive market, goods are homogeneous.

questions.text: What is a 'kinked demand curve' used to describe in oligopoly theory?
options: Highly elastic demand for a product.
Relatively stable prices due to mutual interdependence.
A single firm with no competition.
Firms having very little market share.
questions.explanation: A kinked demand curve describes relatively stable prices due to mutual interdependence in an oligopoly.

questions.text: How might the presence of an oligopoly affect consumer choice compared to a perfectly competitive market?
options: Consumers will have more product choice.
Consumers will have less product choice.
Oligopoly will have no impact on the amount of choice that consumers have.
Consumers will have access to homogeneous products
questions.explanation: The presence of an oligopoly may result in less product choice for consumers compared to a perfectly competitive market.

questions.text: In evaluating an oligopolistic market, which of the following is the most relevant factor to analyze?
options: The total number of firms in the industry
The extent of barriers to entry
The level of product differentiation and the degree of collusion.
questions.explanation: The extent of barriers to entry is the most relevant factor to analyze in an oligopolistic market.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not the objective of macroeconomics analyzing?
options: It helps to understand how individual economy growth
It helps to understand how to nation increasing economic growth
It helps to understand how inflation is controlled
It helps to understand how the domestic economy interacts with the rest of the world
questions.explanation: Macroeconomics analyzing helps to understand how the national economy grows, not individual economy growth.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct?
questions.explanation: GNP = GDP + NFI (Net Factor Income from abroad).

questions.text: Consumer Price Index in 2001 E.C is 140, and in 2002 is 120, then, what is the inflation rate from 2000 to 2002?
What is the minimum amount of remuneration that an employer is required to pay to wage earners for the work that is performed during a given period?
questions.explanation: The minimum amount of remuneration that an employer is required to pay to wage earners is minimum wages.

questions.text: What are the types of inflation, if the inflation rate is 3% to 10%?
questions.explanation: An inflation rate of 3% to 10% is considered walking inflation.

questions.text: Which one of the following refers to the recurrent ups and downs in the level of economic activity?
questions.explanation: The business cycle refers to the recurrent ups and downs in the level of economic activity.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not true about GDP?
options: Total income earned by all citizens of the country
The total value of all goods and services sold in economy
The total value of all final goods and services with in a country's border
The total value of goods and services of intermediate in country
questions.explanation: GDP does not include the total value of goods and services of intermediate in the country.

questions.text: In a country A, the price index was 100 in 2003, 125 in 2004 and 150 in 2005. What was the changes to inflation in the country in 2005?
questions.explanation: The price index increased from 125 in 2004 to 150 in 2005, indicating increasing inflation.

questions.text: The phase of business cycle during which business confidence in the economy is at its lowest is known as:
questions.explanation: The phase of the business cycle during which business confidence in the economy is at its lowest is known as depression.

questions.text: Labor force consists of all those:
options: Who are not willing to work
Who are not available for work
questions.explanation: Labor force consists of all those who are fit for work.

questions.text: Suppose the government of Ethiopia decided to build a new school. Which category of Expenditure budget will the money be spent?
questions.explanation: The money for building a new school will be spent from the capital expenditure budget.

questions.text: The Government body responsible for the implementation of monetary policy is
options: Ministry of Finance and Economic Development
questions.explanation: The National Bank of Ethiopia is responsible for the implementation of monetary policy.

questions.text: Macroeconomic policy reforms taken in Ethiopia include
options: A tight monetary policy to ensure macro-economic stability
An exchange rate policy which revalued birr to encourage exports and discourage imports
A fiscal policy undertaken to increase fiscal deficit
Interest rate policy which imposed interest rate ceiling on borrowers
questions.explanation: An exchange rate policy which revalued birr to encourage exports and discourage imports is a macroeconomic policy reform taken in Ethiopia.

questions.text: Who is the economist mostly close to associated with monetarist school thought?
questions.explanation: Milton Friedman is mostly associated with the monetarist school of thought.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the best description of the inflation?
options: A situation where unemployment is low
An increase in general price level of goods and services
A decrease in general price level of goods and services
questions.explanation: Inflation is an increase in the general price level of goods and services.

questions.text: Under fixed exchange rate policy, what is an increase in the exchange rates due to political and economic decisions of the government?
questions.explanation: An increase in the exchange rates due to political and economic decisions of the government is called devaluation.

questions.text: Which one of the following factors causes an increase of one country GDP?
options: Decrease in the value of export
questions.explanation: An increasing value of investment causes an increase in one country's GDP.

questions.text: In the case of inflationary gap:
questions.explanation: In the case of an inflationary gap, aggregate demand (AD) is greater than aggregate supply (AS).

questions.text: Aggregate demand is determined by:
questions.explanation: Aggregate demand is determined by the state of technology.

questions.text: To control the situation of deficient demand, what is the government measurement?
questions.explanation: To control the situation of deficient demand, public borrowing is increased.

questions.text: What is the role of central bank to control the situation of excess demand?
options: The central bank reduces bank rate.
The central bank sells government securities.
questions.explanation: The central bank sells government securities to control the situation of excess demand.

questions.text: A reduction in bank interest rate is:
questions.explanation: A reduction in bank interest rate is an expansionary monetary policy.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the components of aggregate demand that includes output, the cost of capital and expectation about the future.
questions.explanation: Investment is the component of aggregate demand that includes output, the cost of capital, and expectation about the future.
C + I + G + (X - M) represents aggregate demand.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not true about aggregate demand?
options: The total amount of money which all sectors spent.
All spent of money households, firms, and governments
Sum of spending by consumers, businesses, and governments which depends on the level of prices
Total amount of goods and services different sectors in the economy willingly supply
questions.explanation: Aggregate demand is the total amount of money which all sectors spent, not the total amount of goods and services different sectors in the economy willingly supply.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT the determinant of aggregate demand?
options: General level of income of the people
questions.explanation: Taste of the preference is not a determinant of aggregate demand.

questions.text: The Keynesian aggregate supply curve is:
questions.explanation: The Keynesian aggregate supply curve is horizontal.

questions.text: An increase in aggregate demand:
questions.explanation: An increase in aggregate demand raises the aggregate level of prices.

questions.text: Suppose that the nominal wages is $30 an hour, and the price level as measured by price index is 1.50. What is the real wages?
questions.explanation: Real wages = Nominal wages / Price index = $30 / 1.50 = $20.

questions.text: Aggregate demand curve is typically:
questions.explanation: The aggregate demand curve is typically downward sloping.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not the components of aggregate demand?
questions.explanation: Aggregate supply is not a component of aggregate demand.

questions.text: What is the market failure in economics?
options: An inefficient distribution of goods and services in the free market.
An efficient distribution of goods and services in the free market.
An inefficient distribution of goods but not services in the free market.
An efficient distribution of services but not goods in the free market.
questions.explanation: Market failure is an inefficient distribution of goods and services in the free market.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not the cause of market failure?
questions.explanation: In perfect competition is not a cause of market failure.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not the example of pure public goods?
questions.explanation: Food is not an example of pure public goods.

questions.text: A positive externality exists when:
options: Third party incurs a cost from transaction
The market produces too much of a good
A third party benefits from a transaction
questions.explanation: A positive externality exists when a third party benefits from a transaction.

questions.text: According to A.C. Pigou, which one is not a solution assumption of externality?
options: Externality is the difference between MSC and MPC
A firm producing output and emitting smoke.
The external cost of pollution is borne by others.
questions.explanation: There is no competitive industry is not a solution assumption of externality.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about externalities?
options: Externalities can be either positive or negative.
Externalities can be generated by only consumers
Externalities are not reciprocal in nature
Externalities can be generated by only producers.
questions.explanation: Externalities can be either positive or negative.

questions.text: When there is negative externality:
questions.explanation: When there is a negative externality, MSC < PMC.

questions.text: What is a situation in which different agents have a different amount of information about a good, when one party in a transaction is in possession of more information than the other?
questions.explanation: Asymmetric information is a situation in which different agents have a different amount of information about a good.

questions.text: Which types of asymmetric information is situations where one side of the market cannot observe the 'type' or quality of the goods on the other side of the market?
questions.explanation: Hidden information problem is a situation where one side of the market cannot observe the type or quality of the goods on the other side of the market.

questions.text: What is the goal of consumer’s protection?
options: To safeguard the interest and rights of consumers only.
To measures adopted for the protection of consumers as they affected by unscrupulous
To provide them with speedy redress of their grievances.
questions.explanation: The goal of consumer protection is to safeguard the interest and rights of consumers and to measures adopted for the protection of consumers as they affected by unscrupulous.

questions.text: Which one of the following arguments that favors of consumer protection, when business must be guided by certain social and ethical norms?
questions.explanation: Social Responsibility is an argument that favors consumer protection when business must be guided by certain social and ethical norms.

questions.text: The main objectives of the Consumer Protection Act in Ethiopia are to:
options: Protect the business community from anti-competitive and unfair market practices
To discourage a competitive free market.
Ensure that consumers get goods and services less safe guarded.
To accelerate economic development and unscrupulous market
questions.explanation: The main objectives of the Consumer Protection Act in Ethiopia are to protect the business community from anti-competitive and unfair market practices.

questions.text: What is the general objectives of macroeconomic policy?
options: To decrease rate of economic growth
To achieve full employment and price stability
To equality in the distribution of income
questions.explanation: The general objectives of macroeconomic policy are to achieve full employment and price stability.

questions.text: Which economic thought believed that an automatic mechanism works to restore stability in the economy recession would cure itself and inflation will be automatically controlled?
questions.explanation: Classical economic thought believed that an automatic mechanism works to restore stability in the economy, recession would cure itself, and inflation will be automatically controlled.

questions.text: Which one of the following is excluded under the government spending?
options: Purchase of weapons for the military
questions.explanation: Capital gains from investment are excluded under the government spending.

questions.text: Which types of tax the government imposes on export and import goods?
questions.explanation: The government imposes tariffs on export and import goods.

questions.text: What do you think would be the sign of the net exports (NX) of Ethiopia?
questions.explanation: The sign of the net exports (NX) of Ethiopia is positive.

questions.text: The total market value of all final goods and services which are produced annually by resources of a country irrespective of the location of these resources.
questions.explanation: GNP is the total market value of all final goods and services which are produced annually by resources of a country irrespective of the location of these resources.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT parts of consumption expenditure?
questions.explanation: Investment is not a part of consumption expenditure.

questions.text: When there is a single owner, these types of business form is:
questions.explanation: Sole proprietorship is a type of business form with a single owner.

questions.text: Product differentiation is a typical feature of:
questions.explanation: Product differentiation is a typical feature of monopolistic competition.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not method of measuring GDP?
options: Value of final goods and services in economy
Sum of value added in economy
questions.explanation: Sum of incomes is not a method of measuring GDP.

questions.text: What is the types of unemployment exists due to technological change?
questions.explanation: Structural unemployment exists due to technological change.

questions.text: Which one of the following factors shifts the aggregate demand curve to the right?
questions.explanation: An increase in future expectation shifts the aggregate demand curve to the right.

questions.text: Which one of the following is most likely to cause decrease in aggregate demand?
questions.explanation: A decrease in the consumer price index is most likely to cause a decrease in aggregate demand.

questions.text: The increase in spending that occurs because of the increase in the real value of money, when the price level falls is called
questions.explanation: The increase in spending that occurs because of the increase in the real value of money, when the price level falls, is called the wealth effect.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of marginal propensity to consume (MPC)?
options: The total amount of income spent on consumption.
The proportion of total income that is saved.
The change in consumption resulting from a change in income.
The average level of consumption over time
questions.explanation: MPC is the change in consumption resulting from a change in income.

questions.text: If the marginal propensity to save (MPS) is 0.2, what is the marginal propensity to consume (MPC)?
What is the primary purpose of investment in economics?
options: To increase future production and income.
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of investment in economics is to increase future production and income.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a component of business investment?
questions.explanation: Government bonds are not typically considered a component of business investment.

questions.text: What does the term 'present value' refer to in the context of investment?
options: The original cost of an asset
The current value of a future sum of money.
The expected profit from an investment.
The total costs associated with an investment.
questions.explanation: Present value refers to the current value of a future sum of money.

questions.text: Suppose BEKELE has a monthly income of $3,000 and he wants to save 15% of it. What is the amount he allocates to save in each month?
What would be the consequence of a country consistently having a trade deficit?
options: A consistent increase in the country's GDP
A constant increase in the country's standard of living
A decrease in the country's net exports which negatively affects the GDP
A significant increase in local production
questions.explanation: A consistent trade deficit leads to a decrease in the country's net exports, which negatively affects the GDP.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key measure of national income?
questions.explanation: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is a key measure of national income.

questions.text: The expenditure approach to calculating GDP includes which of the following components?
options: Consumption, investment, government spending, and net exports.
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach to calculating GDP includes consumption, investment, government spending, and net exports.

questions.text: Which approach to measuring GDP is most likely to be affected by changes in inventory levels?
options: The production and income approaches are equally affected by inventory.
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach to measuring GDP is most likely to be affected by changes in inventory levels.
